description:
Translated from the Box:

Once and for all decide which sex is the strongest!
De Jongens Tegen De Meisjes (The Boys Against the Girls) is a battle between men and women. In seven different rounds plus a final round two teams play against each other. Bet on the opponent's answers wisely and collect the most coins to win the game.

A dice-rolling game where you (and up to 5 more friends) explore an ancient dungeon with monsters and treasure! Defeat the boss monster, and win the game!

On each of your turn, navigate the dungeon to encounter monsters and treasure. If you encounter a monster, only one of you lives!

SQUASH the competition in the farming game that grows on you!

Share a plot of land between your friends and compete to harvest the most zucchini. During your turn, you have the choice to lengthen a vine or grow a zucchini in size. Once you grow a zucchini to 3 cards in length, draw an Action Card. You might get to fertilize your plants, kill your opponents' chances with blight, or harvest a vine for points. The first player to 30 points is the winner!

It's time to get growing.

Burgle Bros. is a cooperative game for 1-­4 players. Players are unique members of a crew trying to pull off a robbery of a highly secure building — without getting caught. The building has three floors (4x4 tiles), each with its own safe to crack. Players start on the first floor and have to escape to their helicopter waiting on the roof.

Players each have three stealth tokens. Whenever they are on the same tile with a guard, they lose one. If any player is caught without a stealth token, the game is over. If players can open all three safes, and escape through the stairs to the roof they win.

Let’s go see the Wizard of Oz

Based on the public domain book The Wonderful Wizard of Oz is a children’s novel written by L. Frank Baum and illustrated by W. W. Denslow.

Follow the Yellow Brick Road is a tabletop game. It is a bit like Candyland but with some strategy.

Help Dorothy, the Lion, the Scarecrow and the Tin Man in their quest to find the Wonderful Wizard of Oz. Follow a path with many challenges and stunning surprises in this fun game for 2 to 4 players aged between 9 and 99 year old (more or less).

Play a game in 15 to 30 minutes with a balance mix of chance and strategy. Will you be the first to reach the Emerald Castle? Will the Good Witch of the North help you with Silver Shoes? Beware of the Wicked Witch of the West and her Winged Monkeys. The Wonderful Wizard of Oz will bring more surprises.

Information from the back of the box:

Use your ninja skills to knock down villains (Shredder, Kraang Droid, and Foot Clan Soldier) by hitting them with pizzas launched from your pizza catapult! With four catapults launching pizzas at the sae time, it's pies to the sky, dude.

An educational game aimed at preschoolers, where the point is to match shapes, colours and numbers. It is played as a lotto game – tiles are drawn from a pool, and are placed on matching squares on the players' boards. The twist is that the active player does not show the tile to the others, but instead calls out the type, colour and number of shapes depicted (e. g. "six red triangles"). The first to cover all squares on their board is the winner.

“Moew~! Those boxes are mine. All mine!”
It’s known that cats are obsessed with cardboard boxes and in Cat Box they fight for them!

Goal of the game
Players will have a secret CAT color (identity) and the winner is the player with the most cats visible of his type in the center of the table when the game ends.

Components
Cat cards x 20 (double-sided will either cats or empty boxes in 2 x 2 grid)
Cat Identity card x 4 (1 of each color)

Player turn

1) Player chooses one out of two possible actions:

a) Play a card from hand

b) Use a card from another player's hand

2) Draw back up to 2 cards.

Game End
The game ends when all players have no cards in hands. Players reveal their Cat identities and count the number of their cats that are visible in the table. Each visible cat earns the corresponding player 1 victory point (VP).

Cave Pilot 55 is an 'Arcade' card-board game where 1-4 players race their sophisticated technological bat-planes through a gauntlet cave. Players jointly contribute to the construction of the cave.

The goal of the game is to finish alive with the most experience points gained during the race.

Each turn, player's put a small part of the cave on the table, representing either the ceiling or the floor of the cave. By doing so, a long small cave is created on which different dangerous objects or animals (vampiric bat, giant centipedes, laser beams, etc) are shown. During movement the bat-planes fly either along the cave ceiling or along the cave floor until they arrive at a cave and have to encounter its horrors. The dice-fight that follows during an encounter can be won (experience points are gained) or lost, depending on the strength and equipment of the bat-plane. Players can strengthen their bat-planes by upgrading various parts of their plane (shields, short-range attack, plate armor, power, maneuverability and navigation & control), however only at specific locations in the cave. Players can not only invest their money in upgrades, they can also decide to buy long-range missiles or booster fuel. The long-range missiles can be used to shoot rivals, caves and obstructions. Booster fuel is used to outmaneuver other players by playing an extra turn or to move diagonally. Some cave locations also offer the possibility to explore the local environment, and with a bit of luck player's  might find special upgrades there.

Each game, the layout, the length and the difficulty of the cave is different. It is a tactical game, thrilling to the last turn, based on a few simple rules, in a steampunk sci-fi technological world, where players have to continually cope with limited resources.

Players race as kangaroos to the finish line, dodging obstacles, and sabotaging the plans of others in the Outback.  Each kangaroo has a special ability and can use that ability along with purchasing Item Cards to give them an edge in the race.  When two kangaroos land in the same space they box each other and betting takes place.  It's a fight to the finish line.

Seafari Under the Sea is a spin-and-move game where players move around a track of bubbles "under the sea."  Each player has a puzzle picture card, and all the puzzle pieces are face-down on the table.  As they move, players land on spaces that allow them to pick one, two or three puzzle pieces.  They must take face-down pieces and try to match them to their puzzle.  If they match, the may be added to the puzzle.  If not, they are returned to the face-down pile.  Some spaces also force players to put a puzzle piece back or stay on the space until a certain number is spun.  The first player to complete his or her puzzle wins.

The Ten Million Year FilmCow Wars is a card game starring many of your favorite and least favorite FilmCow characters. It can be played by 2-4 people, and each game lasts around 15-30 minutes.

Can you score more points than your friends and/or bus stop acquaintances? I have no idea, maybe. I am not a mystical seer. The veil of time covers even my eyes."

The game is played by drawing s hand of cards and choosing one to play and one to discard. Each card falls into one of 5 color coded "suites". The first player to collect one of each suit wins the game. Each card features conditions such as requirements to play, or effects that happen once in play.

Publisher's Description:

Be the first to get your X-Team to the X-Mansion!  There's danger in the air!  Juggernaut, that unstoppable engine of destruction, is roaming about the X-Mansion.  Professor X's life is at risk.  He telepathically calls his X-Men to the rescue.  However, they are already on a mission to prevent Magneto from enrolling the Morlocks and their leader, Callisto, into his deadly plans.  Help the X-Men stop the villains and restore safety to the X-Mansion.

X-Men was published as part of the Marvel Comics Super Heroes Game Book, and the board is a double-page spread of the book which is laid flat to play. It is in the Pachisi/Sorry family.  Each player has four markers. A roll of 4 is needed to get a marker on the start space. After that, they must enter a track and make their way around to their color of ladder  They must then make their way up the ladder and roll the exact number to land on the X-Mansion.  Along the way, if they land on another player's marker, they may either send it back to the start or take another turn. Spaces marked with villains move the marker backward or cause loss of a turn. The first player to land all four markers on the X-Mansion wins.

Each player is a farmer living in the remote village of Farmaria. The aim of the game is to grow their farm and col-
lect as many Victory Points, (V.P.) as possible. On the Farm are a number of fields and commodities owned by each player. The V.P. represent the reputation of every player in Farmaria along with the quality of their farm. The game requires strategy along with commercial and business development aptitude.

This is a Strategy game for 2 to 5 players The players invest on their farms using an Action Choice Token System while at the same time the try to upgrade their property in an efficient way, stop other players from winning or interrupt their plans and avoid catastrophic events. The player with the most Victory Points wins the game.

You are in charge of a stable of Knights that each have their own Knightly ability. Your Knights are going to the King's Jousting Tournament in order to joust against Knights from another House. You will roll dice to show your prowess and might.  Use your influence gained during jousting to gain workers. You can increase the ability of your Knights with dice, cards, and powers!

Buying ingredients, greeting guests, serving tables — running a restaurant can be hectic, and in the end only the one who is "Da Luigi" can keep an overview of everything and earn a star for the restaurant. If only you didn't have to deal with the other players who always act as unwelcome guests...

Your goal in Da Luigi is to get as many guests as possible, although only satisfied customers will always be good customers. Variety in the gameplay comes from the 90 individual guest cards, with you always wanting to find a free table for wealthy guests with plenty of time while pushing off grumpy customers in a hurry to your opponents.

Players buy ingredients for their meals from the market and pay for them in time — and time is always against you because if you don't serve a guest his desired food quickly, say, by the end of the game, you'll lose points in the end.

Knätsel?!, a reworking of the 1988 Spiel des Jahres-winning Barbarossa, challenges players to create and decipher "knätsels", i.e., kneading puzzles. (In the U.S., this game bears the title Dohdles!, a portmanteau of "dough doodles".)

In the game players use clay to create objects — a mountain, an animal, a famous ruin — then they take turns asking one another questions about these objects or asking for a letter in the name of this object. Everyone hears these requests, though, so your efforts might lead opponents to the correct answer, too, and since anyone can throw their solution stones into the answer funnel at any time, you'll need to think fast.

If you give the correct answer for a puzzle, both the creator and guesser score points — but if everyone guesses the answer, or conversely no one does, then the creator scores nothing. Who will find the ideal mix?

Publisher's Description:

Race to Florida!  The United States is on RED ALERT!  Red Skull is threatening to spread his infamous dust of death all over the country.  All the states, except Alaska and Hawaii, are at risk.  It's up to you, the Avengers and Force Works, to get to Florida as quickly as you can and put an end to Red Skull's deadly plan.  Remember, Kang and his temporal duplicates are out there to prevent you from accomplishing your mission!

The Avengers was published as part of the Marvel Comics Super Heroes Game Book, and the board is a double-page spread of the book which is laid flat to play.  It is a roll-and-move game where players must move four markers (one at a time) in a numbered sequence from state to state on a map of the United States, starting in Washington and ending in Florida.  Some states contain instruction to move forward or back or lose or gain a turn.  If a player lands on a state occupied by another player's token, they must move back five spaces.  First player to reach Florida with all five tokens wins.

Publisher's Description:

Lure Absorbing Man to the Water!  Absorbing Man has decided to eliminate the Incredible Hulk. He has set up a trap for the Hulk in a hydro power plant.  You must join forces with She-Hulk and the Hulk to get rid of Absorbing Man, once and for all.  Here's the plan.  Since Absorbing Man can absorb the properties of anything he touches, She-Hulk and the Hulk will attempt to make Absorbing Man turn himself into fire.  Then they will throw him into the sea, where he will disappear forever!

The Incredible Hulk was published as part of the Marvel Comics Super Heroes Game Book, and the board is a double-page spread of the book which is laid flat to play.  It is a fairly standard roll-and-move game where players must move two tokens representing Hulk and She-Hulk one at at time along a track by rolling an electronic die.  Along the way, some spaces will move players forward or back or cause a loss or gain of a turn.  If a player lands on another player's token, he or she moves back four spaces.  First player to reach the end with both markers wins.

OBJECT:
To win the majority of 9 games played simultaneously.

INCLUDES:
54 pegs
9 up gameboard
Instructions with box

(source: Text on box)

User summary:

The players are lord of house during Victorian England, and must, during six rounds, build up noble fame by having a staff of maids, important connections and land strips.

Each round, a number of cards (maids, noble connections and lands) are laid out, and each player has 2 pawns that he may use to claim cards. Knocking away another player from a card costs money that goes into the treasury; and the treasury can also be claimed. Lands cost money to claim, but brings an income each round.

The 3rd and the 6th round there is a scoring round, in which players get points for maids, combinations thereof, noble connections and land. The player with the most points at the end wins.

Imagine an intricately mechanized clash of spy against spy, introducing corporate espionage to a Steampunk world of industrial revolution; filled with all of the plot twists and thrills of both genres. That's the world of Steam Spy, a Steampunk themed role playing card game for 2 players. Steam Spy unites the character development and narrative of a traditional role playing game with the intimacy and spontaneity of a card game.

Players create a unique secret agent character who works for one of the organizations designated to protect and serve one of the world’s largest corporations.  Then they face off against an operative from an opposing secret industrial organization in a one on one battle of wits, luck and exotic steampunk gadgets.  One player instigates some kind of espionage mission while the other does their best to stop them.

Players collect, play and draw cards that help create a series of exciting encounters that ultimately determine if the instigating antagonists succeeds at their mission, or the determined protagonist chases them down and defeats them; players then advance their spy character, or create a group of secret agent specialists in preparation for the next face off against operatives from opposing agencies and corporation.

Steam Spy: Shadows and Circuits allows you to investigate the mysterious as an agent of the Shadow Bureau, the Eastern European agency that helps protect the lines of transportation developed by the Transylvanian Transportation Company. Or you can join the Dragon Sect and take advantage of the marvelous technology developed by its parent company Orisaku Artificials.

Unspeakable Words is the Call of Cthulhu Word Game designed by James Ernest and Mike Selinker. In the game, you and your opponents will attempt to form words from the letter cards in your hand. Each letter is worth points – the amount of points is determined by the number of angles in the letter (where the hounds of Tindalos are lurking!). You may try to make the highest scoring word possible, but… you’ll have to test the strength of the word against a roll of the 20-sided die. Roll equal to or higher than the value of your word and you’re safe… but roll less than the value of your word and you lose a precious piece of your sanity, represented by an adorable Cthulhu pawn!

Each letter is uniquely illustrated with a horrifying character from the works of H.P. Lovecraft, which adds to the dark whimsy of the game.

Since its release in 2007, Unspeakable Words has been received with great reviews. It was Games Magazine's Word Game of the Year and the Best Party Board Game at BoardGameGeek's Golden Geek Awards.  In 2008, a second edition of Unspeakable Words was released, this time with purple pawns. Because of the flexibility of the game, a second deck and second set of pawns can be added for twice as many players.

Since the inception of Unspeakable Words, Playroom Entertainment has wanted to release more specialized editions. With this Kickstarter, supporters can upgrade the Unspeakable Words game with special multi-colored pawns (five pawns each of eight colors to play up to eight players!), a dice/pawn bag and additional cards! AND...this Deluxe Edition will feature artwork by famed artist John Kovalic! Plus, if we hit our stretch goals, even more amazing things will be added to the game!

In the Dungeons & Dragons: Temple of Elemental Evil Board Game, you play as a heroic adventurer. With amazing abilities, spells and magic weapons, you must explore the dungeons beneath the Sword Coast where you will fight monsters, overcome hazards and find treasure. Are you ready for adventure?

Temple of Elemental Evil includes multiple scenarios, challenging quests, and co-operative game play designed for 1-5 players. The contents can also be combined with other D&D Adventure System Cooperative play board games, including The Legend of Drizzt and Castle Ravenloft.

Each player selects a hero, such as a fighter, cleric, or wizard. On their turn, each player can explore further into the dungeon (turn over new tiles), move through the already explored parts of the dungeon, and fight monsters. When a new dungeon tile is revealed, there is typically an encounter of some sort, and new monsters to fight are added. Slain monsters reward the players with treasure, and experience points, allowing them to level up and increase their skills during play. Players must cooperate to stay alive, slay the monsters, and achieve the goal of their quest. Each scenario has a different goal, from retrieving a relic to slaying a large boss monster.

Integrates with:

    Dungeon Command: Blood of Gruumsh
    Dungeon Command: Curse of Undeath
    Dungeon Command: Sting of Lolth
    Dungeon Command: Tyranny of Goblins
    Dungeon Command: Heart of Cormyr


Can also integrate with:

    Dungeons & Dragons: Castle Ravenloft Board Game
    Dungeons & Dragons: The Legend of Drizzt Board Game
    Dungeons & Dragons: Wrath of Ashardalon Board Game
    Dungeons & Dragons: Temple of Elemental Evil Board Game
    Dungeons & Dragons: Tomb of Annihilation Board Game
    Dungeons & Dragons: Waterdeep â€“ Dungeon of the Mad Mage Board Game
    Dungeons & Dragons: Ghosts of Saltmarsh Board Game

Uncertainty didn't kill the cat, but that doesn't mean it's not dead. Dr. Erwin Schrödinger and Werner Heisenberg taught us that. We've all heard about the cats in boxes experiment, and maybe we're even curious about the results — but attempting such an experiment would be INSANE in real life! Now you can try your hand at challenging the uncertainty principle without risking the lives of innocent kittens or exposure to radioactive particles! Awww!

In Schrödinger's Cats, players run experiments, form hypotheses, and try to one-up each other's research. Players take on the role of a cat physicist such as Albert Felinestein, Sally Prride, or Neil deGrasse Tabby. Using their special ability to help prove their hypothesis — or at least debunk someone else's — each cat physicist tries to determine the minimum number of alive cats, dead cats, or empty boxes across all the boxes in Schrödinger's lab.

In more detail, each player starts with six cards in hand, along with a physicist card. The first player asserts how many identical cards — whether live cat, dead cat, or empty box — are present among all the cards in play. The next player can increase the number of this claim or call. Each player can use their ability once during the round.

When a player does call, whoever was right — whether about the claim or about doubting that claim — stays in the game, while the other player is eliminated. Each remaining player gets a new hand with one fewer card, and you keep playing rounds until only one player remains.

Originally an expansion for Exploding Kittens, the most successful Kickstarer project ever, that contained cards that were too horrific and/or incredible to be included in a kid safe version. As a stretch goal this was turned into a stand alone game that can be combined with the standard Exploding Kittens deck. If you combine the two decks, you can go up to 9 players. 10 with Imploding Kittens

Leonard, Howard and Raj want a killer robot; Penny, Bernadette and Amy a preserved snowflake; and Sheldon? How about a "device for virtual presence"?

The Big Bang Theory: Das geniale Spiel challenges you to fulfill the wishes of the seven main characters from the television show, and you do this through two-colored cards that allow you to play them on one side or the other. Paradox tiles can change up the rules.

Kiqsuyapi - A game for three to eight players who are puzzle fans and fast thinkers. Here the players themselves decide about the level of difficulty, because they take turns in being the puzzle master who can ask the questions, and it is totally up to him or her what is asked: How many feathers were there altogether? How many headbands were worn? Or how many weapons were pointing to the left? Was the second Indian from the right painted with war paint? Or is there an Indian wearing a shirt, and carrying a tomahawk? The player who is able to give the first correct answer, gains a token.

The 10 playing cards in Kiqsuyapi are double-sided. They determine the level of difficulty of the game. With only 4 cards, the challenge is still moderate. With 10 cards even true champions are going to work up a sweat. And if you still consider this too easy, the expert version will be an even greater challenge for you. Here, all players have to answer and the right answer will gain you a point, as before. Wrong answers, however, will cost you points! This applies in particular to those questions that ask for two or even three aspects at once. For example, how many Indians are wearing a shirt, a headdress and are carrying a bow?

In the dice game ZomBee, you need to stay calm, reveal the right flowers, and (perhaps) get a lucky hand as well because if you reveal a "ZomBee" by mistake, you must lose all of your honey drops.

On your turn, you roll the dice up to three times, trying to give these cubes to your opponents. For each flower on a die, a player must reveal one tile, passing the risk of the other dice to whoever's next.

Players score points for having the most mushroom baskets in Panik Pilze, and to make this happen players should collect as many different types of fungi as possible. Also, you might want to lay your hands on the baskets owned by other players...

Posse: Wild West Justice is a wild west themed card and dice game for 2 to 4 players.

Players are lawmen tasked with capturing the outlaws terrorizing the local population. Players will recruit posse members to help bring the lowdown lawbreakers in for some wild west justice. The player that collects the most reward money wins the game.
Simple roll-and-move-game. The first player to reach space 120 wins the game. The angular spaces are event-spaces, which are explained in the game rules..

Ether Wars is a strategy board game, based on extraction and resource management as well as in combat and enemies domination. A game with a high replayability and a large number strategic combinations, where your decisions will depend of each movement of your enemies and environmental events.

The game is set in a fantastic science fiction scenario. The planet “Etheria”, the only place in the universe where you can find the “Ether”, the most powerful energy in its purest form. The “Ethereals”, the old inhabitants of this planet time ago disappeared. They chose the highest elite of the universe, “The Council” to protect the power of the Ether. “The Wars”; An old tradition, a tournament organized by the Council where the different species of the universe fight to prove their skills over the others and make their champion part of the Council to own and protect the true power of Ether.

The goal is to get a certain number of Ether, which depends according to the number of players. Once a player gets 5, 6 or 7 Ethers (4, 3 and 2 players respectively) wins the game.

The game uses an innovative dice-piece system.  Facing abstract strategy, turn placement as well as an important probability calculus to make the better decision. Along with it, a card mechanical will give the players the chance to surprise and create strategies that affect the elements of the game, including the fate.
The game is divided into days, composed of a series of phases, each with its own characteristics and that are executed successively. These days will happening until a player achieves the goal.
Players can choose one between the four species that are facing the Wars, each with their own skills and characteristics. They will command their army under the Hero orders and will face difficult strategic decisions. Choose the best tactic for each moment to extract the different resources of the planet, fight the enemy, defend your base and fight for the Ether domination.

It is a game that seeks to encourage mainly the strategy and the improvisation skills in the players.

Draftamania: Rise of the promotions is the fast-paced card game of wrestling promotion management. A game of Draftamania takes place over a number of turns. Each turn comprises of three phases:

The Pre-Show phase - Where players draft wrestlers to their roster and buy special Booster cards (to both improve their Roster and to hinder their opponents). Each player draws a House Show card and books their wrestlers to appear in their show. Finally decisions are made about the outcomes of the various segments such as which wrestlers are receiving pushes.

The Showtime phase - Where players take turns describing (commentating) their Show and roll the dice to determine the results of the various Segments. Even the best laid plans and flawless booking can be undone on the night by bad luck, injuries or a crucially timed disruptive Boosters played by an opponent.

The Post-Show phase - In the aftermath of the show players vote to give the best General Manager award to one player. Additionally, gate receipts are calculated, Rosters reorganised and Wrestler’s appeased.

The phases are played simultaneously by the players with the exception of part of the Showtime phase where players take turns to commentate on their own show and roll the dice to decide the results of Segments. During the each of the phases the players will have the opportunity to build a roster of wrestlers for their Promotion.  These wrestlers are further developed with Booster cards, such as pleasing moves, story lines, equipment and arenas, dirty tricks to play on rival player's promotions.

Finally each player will then book their Wrestlers into Shows and Pay-Per-View special events in order to gain Popularity Points (PP). At the end of each Post-Show phase, the players count their Popularity Points; the player who reaches the goal number (different for the different variants) has managed to impress Network TV bosses, signed a TV Network deal and wins the game.

Take Care of Polar Bears is an environment friendly serious game. It offers an opportunity to experience the ecological crisis of Polar Bears indirectly. It gives you the educational values as well, which means that can help to not only understand the causes of climate change problems better, but also know how to deal with them by role-playing in this game.

This board game is played by using cards, not dices basically and the board can be made up with 17 glaciers tiles arbitrarily. There are 54 cards including moving cards, recharging cards, and hunter cards, etc. Players can have three cards in their hands and they use one of their cards in each turn. By using these cards efficiently, the player who reaches the finish tile at first will be a winner. This board game can be used in anywhere, for example, schools, cultural organizations, business training, when someone needs an education about environments or ecological values.

On the farm in Wettpuzzeln auf dem Bauernhof things have been moved around: The cow hides behind the goat shed, the dog is running around the scarecrow, and where is the tractor? Everything is messed up and not even Farmer Paul can be found. Now it's time to quickly find the right parts and clean up the farm once again!

This game attempts to mirror life events many people go through from going to college, raising a family, buying a home, working and retiring.

The intent of the game is to have the most assets at the end of the game.  Assets are earned primarily by passing Payday spots on the game board.  Money is also earned (and sometimes lost) by drawing Action cards, which assign set amounts or multiples of the wheel spin.

There is a very linear board that you move along by spinning a wheel.  There are a handful of intersections where you can choose to go one direction or another but they ultimately have similar spaces and meet back up quickly.  The first one is a decision to either attend college (payment due and a longer track), or not - with different career cards drawn as a result of that decision.  There are a handful of choices regarding house speculation, but for the most part it is a game of luck.

This game makes a number of updates to older games in the game family.  The maximum number of players has been reduced from 6 to 4, and a number of new cards and concepts have been introduced, increasing the randomness of asset collection.

You won't play just one trick at a time in Stichling, but up to four! This introduces many exciting choices: Serve this here? Those cards there? Do I open a new trick? With so many options you need to plan ahead carefully and find the right time to secure the most points.

Can you predict the number of tricks you will win? There are other trick prediction games, but none where you must watch up to 4 tricks at the same time. Make exactly the number of tricks you predict, not one too many, nor one too few. If you lose your concentration for even a minute, your wily opponents will take your tricks away …
The winner is the player who has the most victory points at the end of three rounds.

Swapping card for card gets you closer to the goal in Tausch Rausch: being the first to fulfill five orders. Don't succumb to the noise of the trading and lose sight of the orders or else quicker than you can imagine, an opponent will fulfill that order first.

Award winning game author Martyn F takes you back to the start of civilization. You take on the role of a clan leader and explore the landscape, discover new tools and offer to holy places. All this to gather as much status as possible.

Epoch: Early Inventors is very thematic and tries to stay as close to reality as possible.

Before starting the game you build a landscape of hexagonal playing cards and holy places.

In your turn you can carry out 1 action and/or develop 1 card and/or offer to 1 holy place.

You can choose between the following actions: gather food, fish (for food), hunt for deer, butcher deer, explore adjacent cards or work to get raw material.

You need food to move around the game board and develop cards. Gathering food and fishing are basically the same actions, but depending on the tools you have, the one action might give you more food than the other.

You need raw materials to develop cards and offer to the holy places. Sometimes raw materials can help you to heighten the proceeds of actions. The action "Work" can get you raw materials. The type of landscape you are currently standing on determines how much work it is to get hold of a certain raw material. Raw materials used in the game are: wood, flax, stone, flint, clay and iron ore.

Butchering animals can not only get you food, but also skins, bones and tendons.

Exploring cards adds to your status. It also opens up more cards to be developed.

To develop a card, you need to "pay" the food and materials depicted on the card.

Once you have developed a card, you can use the tool, equipment or knowledge of this card to your advantage. E.g. Rope Making allows you to turn 2 flax into 3 ropes. Sowing gives you 2-4 extra food, when gathering food. An axe makes it easier to chop wood.

By cleverly using your own cards and those of your opponents, you try to offer materials to as many holy places as you can, thereby increasing your status even more.

After 14-20 rounds the game is over. The player that has collected the most status has won.

A simple TCG game with an interesting mechanic about the disposition of card in a 3x3 grid (resembling Tic-Tac-Toe)

There are 4 types of cards: attack (red sword icon), defend (blue shield icon), revitalization (green cross icon) and neutral (yellow circle icon). Also, the cards may have arrows in one or more 8-way directions (up, diagonal up-right, right, diagonal down-right...) Each player starts with a 3x3 grid, 10 points of life and a deck of 25-40 cards. With the flip of a coin is decided the order of playing, at the first turn you must draw 5 cards and play 1 card, for the rest of the match you must have 5 cards in your hand (except when you have 0 cards on your deck)

The purpouse of the game is to combine at least 2 cards to produce a combination of at least 3 symbols. To combine the cards you must put them in the 3x3 grids and achieve to match the arrows (for example, a card in the second row and second column with an up arrow matches with a card with a down arrow that is in the first row and second column). The effect is determined by the greatest symbol value (except neutral, that haves no effect), in case of draw (for example, 2 sword and 2 crosses) the player chooses what effect it should be. Attack effect (sword) deducts 1 point of defence from the life of the opponent for each sword in the combination OR you can disable a card in the rival's 3x3 grid. Defence adds to the player 1 point of life for each shield in the combination. Revitalization can undisable 1 card in your grid.

There are 2 ways to win the game: by reducing the rival's life to 0 OR when the rival have cards in the hand and cannot play a card (the grid is filled with 9 cards that cannot combine in this turn) It should be noted that when a player haves 0 cards in its deck, losses 1 point of life at the start of his turn.

Viaje de España al Japon en Globo, Bicicleta, Vapor y Diligencia (eng. Travel from Spain to Japan with Balloon, Bicycle, Steamboat and Stagecoach) is a vintage spin and move game published in Spain. Players spin the spinning die with 4 paintings on the sides: Balloon, Bicycle, Steamboat and Stagecoach. Player could travel around the board only with that vehicle, which picture he see on the top of the spinning die.
The first player, who cross all route, wins the game.

The Manic Martians Game is a fun game for little ones. Bop a pop-up martian with a space rocket bopper to pick it up.

The Manic Martians Game is fun for two players. Your little one can watch as the martians go in and out of the craters, and then bop one on the head with the space rocket bopper to pick it up! This enjoyable game for 2 players is great fun for children and adults, and easy for little ones to understand.

The game has a round plastic board with small plastic martians set into holes in the board. With batteries, the martians will move up and down in their spaces. Each player has a small rubber mallet and must try to strike the martians with the mallet. A perfect strike will "stick" the martian to the mallet and the player may remove it from the board. The player with the most martians at the end of the game wins.

Pretty girl is a simple game for the younger audiences.
The game contains: board (58x47cm), dice, 8 figurines, 60+24 counters.

On the board is shown part of a city where is a shopping mall. Fields on the board are following streets and sidewalks. In front of stores are marked fields next to which are one or more counters. On the beginning of the game players place their figurines on any field on the board. Figurines are moved in any direction for the number rolled on dice. In order to collect a counter, figurine must stop on marked field and player choose on of counters beside. Players have task to collect as much counters as possible. Every counter represent one clothing item. Assembled set worth extra points. Players also have to visit cafe, hairdresser and bank.

In the Ultimate Brain Challenge you'll need to muster all your mental dexterity to solve riddles, brainteasers, and conundrums. The game includes challenging categories such as Brain Bending Conundrums, IQ Squares, Picture Problems, and Word Mixers.

The goal is to be the first player or team to pass 10 challenges. There is a time limit of 4 minutes per card challenge, but a shorter time limit can be set for faster game play.

Increase your knowledge of Shakespeare and his literary works by playing this fun trivia game. Vote for the correct answers and win some Shillings along the way!

Place your color book pawns next to answers you believe are true. Receive a Shilling for each positive point you earn by selecting a true answer. The player with the most shillings after five rounds wins!

Windy woody is a reaction game with a kite flying theme.

The modular board consists of 5 tiles printed on both sides.
There is one tile showing 6 kites of different colours, one tile showing boys who let the kites fly and three tiles with lines connecting the boys and the kites.

Further there are two dice (colour, task), 6 clothing cards and 21 ribbon cards to count the score.

There are 4 different levels of difficulty. For every level, the players try to be the fastest to grab the right clothing card. The way to determin the right card depends on the level.

Kites colour
Roll the colour die, follow the line form the corresponding kite and check which kind of clothing of the boy flying the kite has this colour.

Missing colour
Roll the colour die, follow the line form the corresponding kite and check which kind of clothing of the boy does not fit the colours (besides the main colour, each kite has 4 additionals clours for the ribbons and spars) of the kite.

Ribbons
Roll the colour die, follow the line form the two kites with corresponding ribbons and check which kind of clothing is identical for the two boys flying these kites.

Combination
Roll the colour die and the task die. The task die tells you according the which of the three rules to play.

The fastest player to grab the correct card scores a ribbon card. 
After every round the board is modified.

The game ends as soon as all ribbon cards are distributed, the player with the most cards wins.

In Death Over the Kingdom you have two games in one:
- For groups of 3 to 7 players;
- For groups of 3 to 16 players, although we recommend starting with
8 players.

The rules explained below are for a game of 3 to 7 players.

The game consists of as many turns as the number of players. Each turn has 3
Rounds where victory condition varies.

- Round 1: The highest card wins.
- Round 2: The lowest card wins.
- Round 3: The intermediate cards win.

Each Round can be won by more than one player, if they match the score or
victory condition. For example, in a 5-player game, up to 3 of them could have
the intermediate card that gives the victory in Round 3.

When all 3 Rounds have been played, the starting player becomes Dealer.
Thereby, all players will be Dealer once throughout the game.
In each Round -in order, beginning with the starting player- players secretly
choose a card from their hand and place it in their playing area face down
They must choose between:
- Exchange your card with the player on the left (they cannot refuse). The
Dealer player has no players on their left. If you’re Dealer and want to
exchange your card, you can do it with the deck, first declaring it aloud. To
do this, you must lift one or more cards at a time without looking. The card
revealed after this cut is your new card.
- To fold, that is, to keep the card that you’ve chosen or that’s been given to
you after a previous exchange.
- Use the ability of the card, if possible (Merchant, Thief, Juggler and Dragon).
- If you have cards in hand, change the card with one of your hand.
Once all the players have played, reveal players´cards to activate the abilities
“At the end of the Round...” of the cards that have this ability (Innkeeper,
Jester, Monk, Sorceress, Knight, Princess and Queen).

The winners of each Round score a point. To indicate that they take the score
markers and place them in their playing area according to their points value.
Once the 3 Rounds have been played, the deck is formed and shuffled again,
and a new turn begins.
When the last Dealer player’s turn is finished, the points are counted. The
SECOND player with the most victory points is declared an absolute winner
of Death Over The Kingdom until the next game!
In case all players are tied in highest and lowest points, no player wins this
game. You will have to play again!

In Mombasa, players acquire shares of chartered companies based in Mombasa, Cape Town, Saint-Louis, and Cairo and spread their trading posts throughout the African continent in order to earn the most money.

"As I expected, the East African Company's network of trading posts has spread far into the West. They were even able to expand into a couple of diamond mines. It seems reasonable to invest our recent yield here in Mombasa, rather than to continue our unrivalled commitment in Cape Town. After all, it can only be to our advantage to have other irons in the fire. And when the day of reckoning comes, it will show whether our hoarding of holdings and our intransigent eagerness are worth it..."

Mombasa is a tense Euro-style strategy game set in 19th century Africa in which players invest in four chartered companies. Using influence to help them expand across the continent improves the value of the players' shares in these companies. Players will also trade in bananas, coffee or cotton, work together with diamond merchants and ensure that the accounts are kept up to date. To make the most of this one will need to have the correct action cards (back) in hand at the same time, which needs excellent forward planning.

Mombasa features a unique, rotating-display hand-mechanism that drives game play: Players start with an identical hand, but acquire new and more powerful cards from the rotating display throughout the game. Each round players choose action cards from their hand, place them face down in the so-called action slot (beneath the player board), and then reveal them simultaneously to carry out the actions. At the end of the action phase, each card is moved to the so-called resting slot (above the player board). Cards in the resting slots are inactive and cannot be used until they are recovered - each round one can only return cards of one resting slot which is why it can make quite a difference in which action slots certain cards are placed.

The game ends after seven rounds, players add up their scores in different categories, and the player with the highest score (who has earned the most money) wins the game. With a variety of paths to victory and double-sided company boards, each game will be a new and different challenge.
